Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Stochastic Models for Designing the Patient Centered Medical Home in Primary Care

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award is to create capacity planning and allocation models to improve timely access, patient-clinician continuity, and care coordination in primary care delivery. Two-stage and multi-stage stochastic optimization methods will be used for this purpose. Specifically, the models will optimize the allocation of care needs arising from patients with different comorbidities and chronic conditions (case-mix classes) to physician-nurse teams. A key part of the proposed framework is modeling the impact of time spent in non-visit care (care provided outside of the face-to-face office visit, through email, phone and/or other means). Non-visit care is important since it provides both providers and patients an alternate method to enhance access, continuity, and coordination, and can also substitute for regular office visits. All project tasks will be carried out in close collaboration with two academic medical centers (Mayo Clinic and Massachusetts General Hospital) and a small family medicine clinic. The project includes plans for dissemination (annual workshops at medical centers), and implementation of results in practice (residency clinics at Massachusetts General Hospital).

If successful, the stochastic models and empirical estimations will provide rigorous quantitative support to inform the operational and financial design of the patient centered medical home that is being adopted nationwide. Ultimately access, continuity and care coordination for patient populations will be positively impacted. The methodologies developed to solve the computationally challenging allocation problems and the resulting insights will have relevance for other service environments. Through this project, graduate and undergraduate students will conduct interdisciplinary research in clinical settings. Additionally, pedagogy in graduate and undergraduate operations research courses will be enhanced through the use of real world healthcare data sets.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this project was to create data-driven capacity planning and scheduling models for designing a model of primary care delivery called the medical home. A medical home promotes timely access, patient-clinical team continuity, and coordination of care beyond the primary care office visit with the goal of improving the patient's health. 

One of the important contributions of this project is the use of detailed patient-level datasets for answering key questions in primary care delivery. Primary care takes a holistic, comprehensive view of a patient's care, so it is only appropriate that the data used to tackle capacity and operational questions in primary care should consider all aspects of the patient's care. Publicly available and organization specific patient-level datasets formed the basis of the new capacity and workload planning methodologies proposed in this project. Specific examples of operational questions answered in this project include: 

(1)  What is the right number of patients (panel size) a primary care physician should care for to provide timely access? How do we quantify the workload generated by face to face office visits and non face to face coordination tasks that physicians and their care teams have to carry out on behalf of the patient?  

(2)  What is the amount of time spent by non-physician care team members such as nurses, community health workers and social workers in helping patients who have both clinical and social needs? How does the care team's effort correlate to patient outcomes? What are best ways to determine staffing decisions for a multidisciplinary care team? 

Patient-level data was used to answer these questions both descriptively and using new algorithms that sampled patient medical histories. This project also contributed to more computationally difficult scheduling problems in various healthcare settings -- primary care, surgical care and emergency care -- using mathematical optimization techniques. 

This project involved six doctoral students, one masters' student and six undergraduate students. One doctoral student was recruited by as part of the NSF-INTERN program in 2018.  

Results have been published in six peer reviewed journal articles and proceedings, and three additional publications are anticipated from the project. Datasets, theoretical models and analysis techniques learned as a result of research were introduced into undergraduate and graduate courses in Industrial Engineering. The primary mechanism was hands-on computational assignments that utilized publicly available available datasets. Student feedback collected over the last five years suggests that the new methods of introducing research into the classroom were successful.

Dissemination to medical practitioners (physicians, nurses and medical administrators) was an important goal of this project. The PI presented research findings through workshops, presentations and plenaries to clinical audiences at the Department of Family Medicine, University of Wisconsin, Madison (2015, 2016, 2017), Mayo Clinic, Minnesota (2015), and Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center, New Hampshire (2018).

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2019
Modified by: Hari Jagannatha Balasubramanian
